title: Would YOU pay extra to be first off the plane?

Holidaymakers are so fed up with queuing to get off the plane that many are willing to pay a fee to exit first, new research has revealed.
In an age when people whinge about fees for checked bags and legroom, a study found 60 per cent of travellers are willing to pay more for premium services to make their journey hassle free and more enjoyable.
The perks that they most want include fast wifi on planes, radio frequency tags to track their bags on their mobile devices, and the ability to send text messages from the sky.
A study found travellers are willing to pay extra to be the first off a plane and avoid being stuck in the aisle
FlightView surveyed more than 2,300 leisure and business travellers to find out what they want from airports and airlines, and what they are willing to pay extra for.
The study found they would spend more cash or use their air miles or rewards points to get a fast, easy and hassle-free experience with no queues, waiting or stops.

While they’re in the air, 64 per cent said they would pay for high-performance wifi if it allowed them to stream their favourite TV programmes or films on their own electronic devices.
Nearly a third said they want to be able to send text messages while they’re en route to their destination.
The study found 22 per cent would pay extra to exit the plane before everyone else.
Holidaymakers are more willing than ever before to pay extra for a fast, hassle-free travel experience
It may come as no surprise that millennials – those born between the 1980s and 2000s – are more willing and likely to pay extra than any other age group.
Mike Benjamin, CEO of FlightView, said: ‘Ultimately, it comes down to convenience, communication and choice.
‘That’s what today’s travellers want and are willing to dig deeper in their pockets for – whether they’re planning a trip, booking their ticket, waiting at the airport, boarding, flying or arriving at their destination.
‘Our survey found that airport and airline executives may be overlooking a real opportunity to drive new revenues and improve the travel experience.’
